text.1: This verse states that Allah SWT swears by *ath-thur*, which is high in status because upon *ath-thur* Allah spoke with the Prophet Musa and revealed the Torah to him, containing laws, wisdom, and good character, and which is easy for people to read. *Ath-thur* means hill, namely Mount Sinai, a hill in Madyan where the Prophet Musa heard the words of Allah SWT. In the Syriac language, *ath-thur* also means a hill with many trees, the place where God spoke directly with the Prophet Musa and in that place he was also appointed as a messenger. It is called *ath-thur* because of its many trees; if there were no trees, it would not be called *ath-thur*, but *Jabal* (mountain). Allah using the mountain as His oath is certainly due to the importance of mountains in the occurrence of life on this earth. Regarding mountains and their role, this can be seen in the discussion of several verses, including Luqman/31: 10 and an-Naml/27: 88. Further discussion can also be seen in an-Naba'/78: 6-7 and an-Nazi'at/79: 30-32.
text.2: Then Allah swt swore by a written book (beautifully inscribed) with its neatly arranged letters. Some are of the opinion that what is meant is Lauh Mahfudz, and others are of the opinion that the meaning of the beautifully inscribed book is that which was revealed and recited to mankind openly.
text.3: Furthermore, Allah swt explains in this verse that the books are easy for everyone to learn their contents. The books contain wisdoms, laws, culture and good character (akhlaq); therefore, they are written on open sheets that can be read.
text.4:
In this verse, Allah swt swears by al-Baitul-Ma'mur, which is a house in the seventh heaven that is entered by 70,000 angels every day to perform tawaf or prayer. Those who have entered it will never return for eternity. This is affirmed in the hadith of Isra': "It is found in Sahih al-Bukhari and Sahih Muslim that the Messenger of Allah saw said in the hadith about Isra' after passing the seventh heaven, then I was raised to Baitulma'mur, suddenly I saw 70,000 angels entering every day and they will not return again after that. (Narrated by al-Bukhari and Muslim)

The meaning of the hadith above is that the angels worship and perform tawaf there (Baitulma'mur) just as humans on earth perform tawaf at the Ka'bah in Mecca. That is the state of the angels. Then Qatadah, Rabi' bin Anas and as-Suddi said that the Messenger of Allah saw one day said to his companions:

"Do you know what Baitulma'mur is?" They replied, "Allah and His Messenger know best." The Messenger of Allah said, "Baitulma'mur is a mosque in the sky that is aligned with the Ka'bah, and if (someone from there) falls, it will fall on the Ka'bah, where 70,000 angels pray every day; when they leave from there, they will not return again." (Narrated by Ibn Jarir)
text.5:
In this verse, Allah SWT swears by the elevated roof (the sky), which is the high realm containing several suns, several moons, fixed stars, and orbiting stars. There also lies His 'Arsh (Throne) and Kursi (Footstool); likewise, His angels (who never reject Allah SWT's commands and are always obedient to what Allah commands them). There are also countless natural objects there, known only to Allah SWT, and Allah SWT's armies whose true nature we also do not know except for He who created them. As explained in Allah SWT's word:

"And none knows the soldiers of your Lord except Himself." (al-Muddatstsir/74: 31)

Sufyan ath-Thawri, Shu'bah, and Abdul Ahwas narrated from Simak from Harb from Khalid bin Ar'arah from 'Ali that As-Saqful Marfu' means 'the sky'. Sufyan recited Allah's word as follows:

"And We have made the sky a protected ceiling." (al-Anbiya'/21: 32)

The meaning is that the sky is a roof, and what is meant by "protected" is that everything in the sky is guarded by Allah SWT with regulations and laws that cause everything to run in an orderly and systematic manner, according to its system and laws.
text.6:
In this verse, Allah swears, "By al-Bahrul-Masjur (the sea in which there is fire)," meaning the sea that is restrained from flooding, because if that sea were unleashed, it would drown everything on earth, so that animals and plants would all be destroyed. Then the laws of nature would be ruined, and there would be no wisdom in the creation of this universe. Some scholars are of the opinion and establish that the earth's layers are entirely like a watermelon, and its crust is like the watermelon's rind. This means that the ratio of the earth's crust to the fire within it is like the watermelon rind to its flesh, which is eaten. Therefore, we are actually standing on a great fire, that is, on a sea that is full of fire underneath, and that sea is covered by the earth's crust from all sides. From time to time, that fire rises to the surface of the sea, as seen during earthquakes and volcanic eruptions; such as the eruption of Mount Vesuvius in Italy in 1909 AD, which swallowed the city of Messina, and the earthquake that occurred in Japan in 1952 AD, which destroyed its cities all at once. According to the majority (Jumhur), what is meant in this verse is the sea of the earth. However, they differ in opinion regarding the word "masjur," among the opinions being that it means: ignited with fire on the Day of Judgment, as in the Qur'an:

"And when the seas are caused to overflow." (al-Infithar/82: 3)

His other saying:

"And when the seas are set ablaze." (at-Takwir/81: 6)
text.7: Then Allah SWT mentions the content of the oath, that the punishments of the Day of Judgment are intended for all who deny the messengers. That punishment will surely occur, without the slightest doubt. The affirmation of the certainty of the coming of the punishment is very important to eliminate doubts among people who doubt the occurrence of that punishment.
text.8: Allah explains that this punishment is something that no one can avert. Nor is there any way to escape from this punishment, which is a recompense for those who have defiled themselves with acts of shirk and sin, and who have tainted their souls with lies against the messengers and the Day of Resurrection. Furthermore, it is explained in this verse that this unavoidable punishment will occur on a day when the sky violently shakes in its place.
text.9: Allah explains that this punishment is something that no one can avert. Nor is there any way to escape from this punishment, which is a recompense for those who have defiled themselves with acts of shirk and sin, and who have tainted their souls with lies against the messengers and the Day of Resurrection. Furthermore, it is explained in this verse that this unavoidable punishment will occur on a day when the sky violently shakes in its place.
text.10:
In this verse, Allah adds the explanation that on the Day of Judgment, mountains will move from their places, moving like the movement of clouds, and flying into the air, then falling to the earth, breaking apart, and then being destroyed into dust like feathers blown by the wind. The shaking of the heavens and the flying of the mountains is a notification and warning to humans that they will not be able to return to the world, because it has been destroyed and a new realm has come into being, namely the afterlife. The verse above relates to the depiction of the occurrence of the Day of Judgment, which is also mentioned in many other verses. Mountains, which express land or the earth's crust, are described as moving places, or in other words, the mountains are moving. This movement of mountains is a manifestation of the movement of the earth's plates (see an-Naml/27: 88) and can cause earthquakes. In Surah az-Zalzalah/99: 1-4, the occurrence of the Day of Judgment is described as the coming of a terrible earthquake. This terrible earthquake can cause long and deep cracks that could possibly trigger volcanic eruptions. As an example, when the Nias earthquake occurred in 2005 with a magnitude of Mw=8.7, after the 2004 Aceh earthquake, several volcanoes on the island of Sumatra showed increased activity.

Scientific facts do indeed show that mountains move. Global Positioning Systems (GPS) data record these movements in millimeters. As an example, the outermost islands west of Sumatra move northeast by 50-60 mm/year.
text.11: In this verse, Allah explains to whom the punishment will be inflicted after the heavens are shaken and the mountains are scattered, namely, to the deniers who wallow in falsehood, constantly reject the truth, do not remember the Day of Reckoning, and never fear the punishment of God.
text.12: In this verse, Allah explains to whom the torment will be inflicted after the shaking of the heavens and the scattering of the mountains, namely, to the deniers who wallow in falsehood, constantly reject the truth, do not remember the Day of Reckoning, and never fear the punishment of God.
text.13: In this verse, Allah explains that those who commit evil deeds, on that Day they will be rebuked and forcibly pushed into Hell, whose fire is always burning and blazing.
text.14: After they are brought near to Hell, the guards confirm with mockery, "This is the Hell which you used to deny in the world." Their denial of Hell means their denial of the messenger who brought news about it, with the revelation that had been revealed to him.
text.15:
Therefore, in this verse, Allah mocks them, namely the polytheists who, when in the world, considered Muhammad (peace be upon him) a sorcerer who bewitched their minds and closed their eyes. Allah mocks them when they are punished in the Hereafter. "Is what they see with their own eyes now, like the torment that was told to them in the world, or are they still lulled by magic as they used to think Muhammad (peace be upon him) bewitched them in the world, or do their eyes see nothing?" Indeed, the torment has become a reality, their eyes are not bewitched, nor are they covered.

Clearly, is there doubt in their vision, or are their eyes sick? No, neither is the case; what they see is the actual reality.
text.16:
When they could not deny the reality and acknowledged that it was neither magic nor the result of misperception, Allah (SWT) commanded them to enter the fire of Hell to feel its heat. Then, Allah (SWT) explained that whether they were patient or not, the situation would be the same for them. Because a person who is impatient with something will try to reject it, either by avoiding it or by overcoming it. However, the Day of Resurrection is different because the torment in the Hereafter is not the same as the torment in this world. For a person who is tormented in this world, if he is patient, he will benefit from his patience, both in the form of reward in the Hereafter and praise in this world regarding his patience and steadfastness. And if he is impatient in the sense of complaining, then he will certainly be reproached and considered childish. However, patience in the Hereafter is of no benefit because the Hereafter is not a place for deeds but for receiving rewards and retribution. At the end of this verse, Allah (SWT) affirms that humans will receive retribution from Allah. If their deeds in the world are good, they will receive a good reward in the Hereafter. And if their deeds in the world are evil, they will receive a reward in the Hereafter commensurate with their evil. Allah says:

"And your Lord does injustice to no one." (al-Kahf/18: 49)

In short, Allah will repay each person according to his deeds. That retribution will be received whether one is patient or not, it will certainly be carried out.
text.17: In this verse, Allah explains that those who fear the wrath of their Lord, they perform worship to Him whether openly or not, fulfill their obligations to God, and carry out the rules of religion, not committing any acts of disobedience, that is, not defiling themselves with sin and not defiling their souls with hypocrisy. To them, God gives the reward of Paradise, in which they will enjoy themselves. They will receive what they have never seen, never heard, and never been described by any human being. All of this is as a reward for their good deeds during their life in the world. They avoid worldly luxuries that make them negligent in worship and are patient with the trials that befall them, hoping to obtain the pleasure of Allah.
text.18: This verse describes them as feeling complete joy and happiness because of the gifts and rewards bestowed upon them by Allah. They are never disturbed by any kind of anxieties or overcome by feelings of fatigue. They are truly in pleasure and enjoyment, with extraordinary delight, their faces radiant, cheerful, and joyful. They have been saved by their Lord from torment. They now feel all pleasures and are far from misery. That is true pleasure and eternal bliss.
text.19:
In this verse, Allah permits them to eat and drink whatever is available in the form of all delicious foods and drinks. They no longer worry about the dangers that will befall them, as they witnessed in the world regarding the dangers of food and drink. All of this is a reward for all their good deeds and a recompense for their earnestness in the world in devotion to Allah swt. They truly feel pleasure in the afterlife. It is narrated that Rabi' bin Hisyam performed prayers throughout the night. Then someone asked him why he exhausted himself like that. His answer was that he needed rest in the afterlife. In a verse with a similar meaning, Allah says:

(It will be said to them), "Eat and drink in satisfaction for what you put forth in the days past." (al-hujurat/49: 17)

The word *hani'an* in this verse means the pleasure of food and drink and being free from all that is harmful. A person who eats in the world sometimes gets sick and other things, so he is less calm and less comfortable eating. Or he is afraid that the food will run out soon so he has to look for it again. Or because it runs out, then he has to cook it again until it is cooked and can be eaten. Things like this will not be found in Paradise. The phrase "bima kuntum ta'malun" in this verse means as a reward for what you have done in the world, this is an indication that Allah has fulfilled what He promised in the world, because no pleasure in the world can be obtained without hard work first. This is different from the pleasures of the afterlife. The pleasures of the afterlife are a reward for faith and good deeds in the world as explained by Allah in His word:

They consider that they have done you a favor by their acceptance of Islam. Say, "Do not consider your Islam a favor to me. Rather, Allah has conferred favor upon you that He has guided you to the faith, if you should be truthful." (al-hujurat/49: 17)
text.20:
Then Allah mentions what they enjoy, for example, their couches (divans). They sit on sofas lined up leisurely without anything burdening their hearts. There is not a single problem they have to face at that time, because whoever sits while facing a problem or burdened by a problem means their mind and heart are not at peace. In this verse, the word *yajlis* (sit) is used, not the word *yattaki'u* (sit leisurely). This is with the intention of explaining the state of sitting of someone who is filled with satisfaction and tranquility. So the state in Paradise indicates a state of peace, without hardship, without burdens, and without problems. In a verse with a similar meaning, it is said:

"Seated on couches, facing one another." (al-Hijr/15:47)

Sitting leisurely is merely an expression as one example of true freedom in Paradise, as the Prophet Muhammad (saw) said: "A person in Paradise sits leisurely for 40 (forty) years without moving and without getting bored, and comes to him (without effort) whatever his soul desires and his eyes delight in." (Narrated by Ibn Abi Hatim) Then it is explained that they there enjoy their spouses. Allah has given them beautiful wives with large, beautiful eyes.
text.21:
In this verse, Allah swt explains that believers who are followed by their descendants in faith will be brought together by Allah in the same level and position as a favor from Allah to them, even if those descendants have not reached that level in their deeds. So that their parents are happy, then their joy is complete because they can all gather together. When reading verse 21, Ibn 'Abbas said that the descendants of believers will be elevated by Allah swt if their level is lower than the level of their parents. Then Allah swt gives a picture of the situation in Paradise full of pleasures, such as the availability of their food in Paradise. Every fruit or food they want, they will surely get according to their taste. Then it is described how they live happily there. They compete with each other to drink, drink with politeness, talk about funny things, there they are served by very friendly and beautiful servants. They also talk about their affairs in the world before they were in the pleasures and luxuries of Paradise. It is narrated that the Messenger of Allah said: When a person enters Paradise, he asks about his parents, his wife, and his children, then it is said to him: "They have not reached your level and deeds." Then he said: "O my Lord, I have worked for myself and for them." Then (his request is granted by God) they (parents, wife, children) are told to join him." (Narrated by Ibn Mardawaih and ath-thabrani from Ibn 'Abbas)

This is a favor from Allah swt towards believing descendants and thanks to the deeds of their fathers, because the father also obtains a favor from Allah swt thanks to their descendants, as the Prophet Muhammad saw said: Indeed, Allah swt will surely raise the rank of a servant, then he asks, "O my Lord, how did I obtain this rank?" Allah answers, "You obtained it because of your child's prayer." (Narrated by Ahmad and al-Baihaqi from Abu Hurairah) From Abu Hurairah that the Messenger of Allah saw said, "When a son of Adam dies, then his deeds are cut off except for three: *amal jariah* (ongoing charity), or beneficial knowledge, or a righteous child who prays for him." (Narrated by Muslim from Abu Hurairah)

Then in this verse, Allah explains again that the reward for the good deeds of righteous fathers is not reduced even though the position of their believing children and wives is raised to the same level as their husband/father as a favor from Allah swt. At the end of this verse, Allah affirms that everyone is indeed only responsible for their respective deeds and actions. The sins of a wife or child are not the responsibility of the father/husband, and likewise the sins of the father should not be burdened on the child or wife. This needs to be emphasized that it is a basic principle. But Allah gives many favors to parents who believe and do good deeds by adding to the happiness of parents to fulfill the wishes of parents to gather in Paradise with their children, wives and grandchildren, as long as they believe, even though their level is lower, but Allah raises them to be the same as the believing and righteous father. If the child is happy to enter Paradise and longs to be with his parents, then Allah bestows His favor, raising his believing parents to have happiness with their children in Paradise. Allah's favor does not change the principle that everyone is only responsible for their own actions, although there are still other exceptions such as the word of Allah swt:

Every soul will be held responsible for what it has done, except the people of the right. (al-Muddatstsir/74: 38-39) Everyone will be held accountable for their actions before Allah swt. That responsibility will not be separated from them except for the people of the right, namely those who do good. These are the ones who will be free from responsibility because of their obedience in worshiping Allah swt.
text.22: Furthermore, in this verse, Allah mentions that He adds to the pleasure of the inhabitants of Paradise from time to time with whatever they desire, such as providing various kinds of fruits and delicious meats, even if they do not ask for them. Why does Allah SWT mention fruits and meats, and not mention various other kinds of food? Because fruits and meats are foods that are liked and contain nutrients necessary for the body and are highly favored in the world. So Allah gives everything that brings pleasure to humans.
text.23:
In this verse, Allah SWT describes their joy in Paradise, which is that each of them takes their drinking glass. They sit toasting with their friends, joking as happens in a group of companions, as an illustration of how cheerful they are. The *khamr* (wine/intoxicant) in the afterlife is not intoxicating like *khamr* in this world, nor does it cause people to speak nonsensically or become drunk like drinkers in this world. Allah SWT has explained in another verse, namely about the *khamr* in the afterlife and the delicious taste of the food, which is the verse that reads in His word:

"(It is) white, delicious to those who drink. There is no bad effect therein, nor from it will they be intoxicated." (as-Saffat/37: 46-47)

And His word:

"No headache will they have therefrom, nor will they be intoxicated." (al-Waqi'ah/56: 19)
text.24:
This verse explains that the inhabitants of Paradise are surrounded by young servants who carry drinks. These servants are always ready to be commanded. They are handsome and beautiful, like pearls that sparkle beautifully and are stored in a hidden place. In a verse with the same meaning, Allah explains: "They will be waited on by immortal youths, with goblets, ewers, and cups filled from a flowing spring." (al-Waqi'ah/56: 17-18) Regarding this verse, Qatadah said, "I heard news that the Messenger of Allah was asked about the servants of Paradise who are like pearls, so what about those who are served?" The Messenger of Allah said: "By Allah, the difference in superiority between them is like the superiority of the full moon night over all the stars." (Narrated by Ibn Jarir and Ibn Mundhir)

It is narrated that the lowest degree in Paradise is for a person who, when he calls his servant, a thousand servants come and stand at his door, answering. "Labbaik, labbaik (Here I am, here I am...)."
text.25: In this verse, Allah SWT explains that the inhabitants of Paradise will visit each other, both between fathers, mothers, and their families who were believers in the world, and also with other inhabitants of Paradise, asking about their condition in the world, which includes worship or various efforts of *nahi munkar* (forbidding evil) because of their fear of Allah's punishment when they were alive in the world. Then they praise Allah SWT who has removed their sadness, sorrow, grief, and anxiety. In Paradise, they no longer feel the hardship and difficulty of earning a living or seeking sustenance and everything related to life. They only enjoy various pleasures. It is narrated that Anas said the following: The Messenger of Allah SAW said, "When the inhabitants of Paradise have entered Paradise and they long for their friends, then a sofa of someone comes close until it faces another sofa, and both sit relaxed while talking and discussing their deeds in the world. Then one of them says, "O so-and-so, do you know on what day the Lord forgave us? On the day in the place where we prayed to Allah and then we were forgiven by Him." (Narrated by al-Bazzar)
text.26: Then, in this verse, Allah SWT details the questioning regarding the various pleasures they enjoy. They say that indeed, when they were in the world, at that time, in the midst of their families, there arose a feeling of fear of Allah's torment and punishment. Then Allah removed that fear by bestowing His blessings upon them, namely that they were protected from the fire of hell, which is called *as-samum*. Their feeling of fear in the world of Allah's torment motivated them to carry out all of Allah's commands and avoid all of His prohibitions, even though at that time they were in the midst of their families, they obtained tranquility. It is narrated that Aisha said, "If Allah were to open hell on earth by the tip of a finger, then the earth and all its contents would be burned."
text.27: Then, in this verse, Allah SWT details the questioning regarding the various pleasures they enjoy. They say that indeed, when they were in the world, at that time, amidst their families, there arose a feeling of fear of Allah's punishment and torment. Then Allah removed that fear by bestowing His blessings upon them, namely, they were protected from the fire of hell called as-samum. Their feeling of fear in the world of Allah's punishment motivated them to carry out all of Allah's commands and avoid all His prohibitions, even though at that time they were in the midst of their families, they obtained tranquility. It is narrated that Aisyah said, "If Allah were to open hell on earth by the tip of a finger, then the earth and all its contents would be burned."
text.28: In this verse, Allah SWT explains that the inhabitants of Paradise have fulfilled the requirements of the call of Allah and His Messenger, thus they attained that glory. They say that they used to worship Allah and supplicate to Him. So Allah granted and answered their requests and accepted their worship, because Allah is the Bestower of goodness, the Giver of bounty, and the Most Merciful. Every believer and every disbeliever will never forget what they did in the world. The pleasure of the believers will increase when they see that they have moved from the prison of the world to the realm of the pleasures of the Hereafter, and from hardship to ease. Conversely, the punishment of the disbeliever will increase when he sees that he has moved from the luxury of the world to the realm of suffering and the misery of Hell in the Hereafter.
text.29:
In verse 29, Allah swt commands Prophet Muhammad saw to continue giving warnings to his people, by teaching them the verses of Allah without regard to their actions that do not contain truth. Allah affirms that His servant, Muhammad saw, is neither a soothsayer nor a madman. As for the disbelievers, they accused Prophet Muhammad saw of being a soothsayer because he gave many unseen news about the past. The people championed by previous prophets also gave news of things to come, such as the Day of Judgment, the Day of Resurrection, and the Day of Reckoning (yaumulhisab), and about Paradise and Hell. This unseen news is a truth received from Allah. So it is clear that the Prophet is not a soothsayer who conveys untrue things. The disbelievers also accused the Messenger of Allah of being a madman because he declared and taught that God is only one, while they considered that their gods, numbering four, could not solve many of the world's problems. If there is only one God, then the world will no longer be preserved, they said. Some Western orientalists stated that the Prophet had epilepsy, such as when he received revelation, he would suddenly become silent and disregard his surroundings, like someone afflicted with epilepsy. But in verse 29, Allah affirms that Muhammad saw is not mad, as the disbelievers accused him. Prophet Muhammad saw is a servant of Allah who was appointed as a messenger, possessing a sound mind, high ideals, and noble morals and behavior. Meanwhile, in verse 30, the disbelievers still accused the Prophet of being a poet because the verses of the Qur'an are very beautiful in language, the structure of the sentences and the choice of words are extraordinary. Poets usually have beautiful language skills and are accustomed to composing sentences and choosing their words unlike ordinary people. According to them, poets often meet death due to accidents. Therefore, they were always waiting for an accident to befall Muhammad saw. In this verse, Allah swt affirms that the Prophet is not a poet. The beautiful language, sentence structure, and extraordinary language choices in the verses of the Qur'an are because those verses are the words of Allah revealed to Prophet Muhammad saw, and Allah will always protect His Prophet. Allah says:

O Messenger! Announce that which has been revealed to you from your Lord, and if you do it not, then you have not conveyed His message. And Allah will protect you from mankind. Verily, Allah guides not the disbelieving people. (al-Ma'idah/5: 67)
text.30:

Allah says:

O Messenger, announce that which has been revealed to you from your Lord, and if you do not, then you have not conveyed His message. And Allah will protect you from the people. Indeed, Allah does not guide the disbelieving people. (al-Ma'idah/5: 67)
text.31: In this verse, Allah SWT affirms to Muhammad SAW that he should threaten them by inviting them to wait for their day of destruction. Muhammad SAW also stated that he too was waiting, like them, for the coming of the decree from the Lord, so that they would know who would end with goodness and who would attain victory in this world and the hereafter. The arrogant attitude of the disbelievers sometimes needs to be confronted firmly. Moreover, their accusations have been excessive, calling the Prophet a sorcerer, a madman, and so on, even though their opinions are based solely on baseless prejudice. Therefore, it needs to be emphasized that the Prophet's message is from Allah the Almighty, therefore the Prophet does not need to be afraid to prove everything until the Day of Judgment.
text.32: Then, in this verse, Allah swt questions whether the disbelievers are using their sound minds or are merely relying on their desires and fantasies in throwing their strange and baseless accusations. The Prophet is indeed not a poet, nor a soothsayer, nor a madman. Their accusations are solely based on excessive hatred, so that they do not pay attention to sound reason at all.
text.33: In this verse, using a question form, Allah clarifies the accusations of the disbelievers that the Prophet was considered to be fabricating, stating something that was invented by Prophet Muhammad saw. This question form is an encouragement for them to think and seek answers using their common sense. The verses of the Qur'an indeed captivated them, both in their language and content, so they said Muhammad was a poet or a sorcerer, even considering him insane. In reality, they were amazed by the verses of the Qur'an, but because they did not believe, they rejected and denied the words of Allah and the prophethood of Prophet Muhammad, so they made baseless accusations. Indeed, they faced a dilemma with the greatness of the Qur'an but also hated Prophet Muhammad saw. Such is the case if a person does not receive guidance (hidayah) from Allah swt, they will suffer inwardly in this world, and suffer both inwardly and outwardly in the hereafter.
text.34: Then, in this verse, Allah answers their various accusations against the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) with a challenge to try and produce something like what the Prophet has conveyed. If Muhammad (peace be upon him) is accused of being a poet, then there are many eloquent poets among them. If the Prophet (peace be upon him) is accused of being a sorcerer, are there not many expert sorcerers among them as well? Or if he is accused of fabricating things, are there not many orators among them, fluent in speech with beautiful diction, and so on? So why are they unable to produce an expression like the Al-Qur'an if they are indeed truthful in their accusations? In fact, they have prominent experts who have great abilities in oratory, poetry, and have a lot of experience working with poetic or prose styles. They know the history of the Arab nation better than Muhammad (peace be upon him) does? Even so, in reality, they are still unable to produce even a single surah like the Al-Qur'an, even if they all work together as a group.
text.35: In this verse, Allah affirms whether the disbelievers deny Allah as the Creator who made this universe, or do they think that they were created so perfectly without a creator. However, reason dictates that everything that exists comes from nothingness. This demonstrates proof that something that brings it into existence must have created it. Or do they think that they themselves created themselves? Such an assumption of theirs is certainly contrary to sound reason, because everything must have something that causes its existence and brings it into being.
text.36: Then in this verse, Allah further emphasizes by stating that if they created themselves, would they also dare to say that they created the universe (the heavens and the earth), while in both are found all the causes of their life? They certainly cannot convince themselves and are not consistent with what they say, because if asked who created them and who created the heavens and the earth, they would surely say, "Allah created it." Indeed, if they believed, they would not deny the Oneness of Allah.
text.37: Furthermore, it is stated in this verse in the form of a question, do they act as rulers and are the treasures of God in their hands? Then they bestow the office of prophethood upon whomever they will and choose those they please? Or are they those who are in power so that they manage the affairs of the universe, then they make something according to their will and desire? The reality is not so. But Allah is the Almighty, who regulates and makes everything that He wills. It is narrated by Imam al-Bukhari from az-Zuhri, from Muhammad bin Jubair bin Muth'im, his father said, "I heard the Prophet Muhammad saw reciting Surah ath-Thur during Maghrib prayer. When he reached verses 35-37, my heart almost felt like it was floating away. And Jubair bin Muth'im had come to the Prophet Muhammad saw after the Battle of Badr as a prisoner. At that time he was still a polytheist. Then he listened to this verse which eventually led him to embrace Islam."
text.38: In this verse, Allah SWT states in a questioning tone, do they have a ladder to ascend to the heavens, then they can listen to the words of the angels about the unseen matters that Allah has revealed? In reality, they only adhere to their own desires. They acknowledge this, so let them present concrete proof, which explains the truth of their acknowledgment that rejects the message, like the proof brought by Muhammad SAW from his Lord.
text.39:
In this verse, Allah SWT asks them, saying, according to them, does God have daughters named angels, while they have sons, even though they know sons are more desirable than daughters? In this verse, Allah says:

"That is then an unjust division." (an-Najm/53: 2)

This is a complete explanation that whoever holds such an opinion, it is clear that they are not among those who have sound minds.
text.40: In this verse, Allah SWT asks them, was it necessary for Muhammad SAW to ask for a wage from the polytheists, whereas he was sent by Allah to them to invite them, to profess the Oneness of God, and to obey Him? If that were the case, wouldn't the wage that Muhammad SAW asked for burden them so that they could not fulfill Muhammad's call? This question refutes their accusations, especially if the Prophet Muhammad were to ask them for a wage.
text.41: Furthermore, in this verse, Allah asks them whether they possess knowledge of the unseen that is unknown to mankind, which they write down for the needs of mankind? Then they inform mankind according to their whims? It is impossible for them to possess knowledge of the unseen because no one knows the unseen of the heavens and the earth except Allah. Qatadah said, this verse is a response to their statement that they are waiting for the turn of time (the death of Muhammad before them). So Allah affirms, do they have knowledge of the unseen so that they know that Muhammad saw will die before them?
text.42: Then in this verse, Allah SWT says to them, do they (the polytheists) intend to deceive mankind and the Messenger with their words about the Messenger and religion? If this is indeed what they desire, then their deception will return to themselves.
text.43: Furthermore, in this verse, Allah says to them, do they have a god other than Allah who can help and protect them from the punishment of Allah SWT. Exalted is Allah above what they associate with Him and from what they worship besides Him. These questions are meant to provoke the disbelievers to find the correct answer based on common sense. This is a strong condemnation of the polytheists, regarding their worship of idols as something they associate with Allah.
text.44:
This verse depicts the polytheists as arrogant and stubborn people. Even when shown signs of the torment that would befall them with the arrival of a cluster of clouds that would bring disaster, they took it lightly and only saw it as a mass of clouds playing and piling up on each other. This was because their hearts were closed and their trivialization of important matters had blinded their vision. They continued to deny what they saw with their own eyes. In a verse with a similar meaning, Allah says:

"And even if We opened to them a gate from the heaven and they were to continue ascending therein, they would say, 'Our eyes have only been dazzled. Rather, we are a people affected by magic.'" (al-Hijr/15: 14-15)
text.45:
Then Allah commanded His Messenger to leave them in that state of stubbornness, and not to heed them until the coming of a day when they would be recompensed with destruction because of their evil deeds, namely in the Battle of Badr as stated by al-Biqa'i according to the apparent meaning of this verse, or until the coming of the Day of Resurrection for mankind in the afterlife, as Allah says:

"And the Horn will be blown, and whoever is in the heavens and whoever is on the earth will fall dead except whom Allah wills. Then it will be blown again, and at once they will be standing, looking on." (az-Zumar/39: 68)
text.46: In this verse, Allah explains that on that Day, the schemes they devised against Muhammad saw to ignite the flames of animosity towards him will be of no avail to them. And they will not receive any help or assistance that can prevent Allah's punishment from befalling them.
text.47:
Allah SWT explains that the disbelievers who wrong themselves with their disbelief and disobedience will receive a painful torment in the afterlife. In addition to that, in this world they also receive torment in the form of famine for seven years before the Battle of Badr, and a great defeat in that war. However, most of them do not know that Allah will inflict His punishment upon them both in this world and in the hereafter. In a verse with a similar meaning, Allah says:

And We will surely let them taste of the nearer punishment (in this world) prior to the greater punishment (in the Hereafter) that perhaps they will return (to the right path). (as-Sajdah/32: 21)
text.48:
After explaining various significant situations that saddened the Messenger's heart due to the defiant and stubborn actions of the disbelievers and polytheists who refused to believe in Allah and His Messenger, in this instance, Allah commands Muhammad, peace be upon him, to be patient with the disturbances of his people and to no longer heed them, but to continue conveying His commands and warning against His prohibitions, and to deliver what has been revealed to him, because Allah always sees him, observes his work, and protects and safeguards him from the disturbances and obstacles of his enemies. Regarding glorifying and praising the Lord when waking up and standing, it encompasses three situations: 1. When waking up from sleep 2. When getting up from sitting 3. When rising to pray. This contains wisdom so that the believer always glorifies at all times, in whatever situation and condition, especially during transitions from one state to another. Atha', Sa'id, Sufyan ats-Tsauri, and Abul Ahwas said: that the Prophet Muhammad, peace be upon him, glorified when he rose from his seat. Some hadith: From Abu Barzah al-Aslami, he said, the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, at the end of his life, whenever he got up from his seat, he would say, "Subhanaka Allahumma wabihamdika asyahadu an la ilaha illa anta astagfiruka wa atubu ilaika! (Glory be to You, O Allah, and with Your praise, I bear witness that there is no god but You, I ask Your forgiveness and I repent to You!)" You are saying something you have never said before. The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, said, "This utterance is an eraser of sins from mistakes that may occur in a gathering." (Narrated by Abu Dawud and an-Nasa'i)

It is narrated that Gabriel taught the Prophet Muhammad, peace be upon him, to recite the following words when about to rise and sit in a gathering: "Mahasuci engkau, wahai Allah, dengan memuji-Mu, aku bersaksi bahwa tiada Tuhan selain Engkau, aku mohon pengampunan-Mu dan aku bertobat kepada-Mu. (Glory be to You, O Allah, and with Your praise, I bear witness that there is no god but You, I ask Your forgiveness and I repent to You.)" (Narrated by Abu Dawud and an-Nasa'i)
text.49:
Then, in this verse, Allah commands Muhammad (peace be upon him) to glorify Allah through night prayer. This is because worship at that time is difficult to perform, far from ostentation (riya), and so that he may pray when the stars disappear at dawn. In a verse with similar meaning, Allah says:

And from [part of] the night, pray with it [i.e., the Quran] as additional [worship] for you; it is expected that your Lord will raise you to a praised station. (al-Isra'/17: 79)

The meaning of reciting tasbih in this verse can mean reciting tasbih as in the hadith above, and it can also be interpreted as performing prayer, whether it be Isha prayer, night prayer, or Fajr prayer.
